Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Turbulent Stress Model in Support of Computational Fluid Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project on the use of computational fluid dynamic (CFD) software for turbulent flows may be transformational. Turbulent flows occur ubiquitously; and, CFD methods are routinely used to assess flow assurance and safety issues associated with industrial scale flows. Although computer hardware and software technologies have advanced significantly, current closure models for the turbulent stress seriously limit the commercial value of CFD methods. Recent research related to the turbulent stress closure problem provides an opportunity to improve the performance of CFD software used to design next generation chemical and nuclear reactors, aircraft engines, automotive engines, and wind turbines for power generation. The proposed innovation will also support prototype designs of hydrocyclone separators as well as prototype designs for next generation industrial mixers.

This I-Corps project offers a software solution to a longstanding problem related to turbulence. Although the turbulent stress closure problem has been a core issue of research for more than a century, a fully-realizable closure model is not presently supported by any commercial software package. This project will address this need by providing complementary software that implements a new class of fully-realizable algebraic stress models consistent with the low-order statistical properties observed in rotating and non-rotating turbulent flows. Most significantly, the closure models are fully-realizable regardless of the benchmark flows selected to calibrate model parameters. This discovery will have a significant impact on the current use of computational fluid dynamic software for turbulent flows.

Background   The Reynolds averaged Navier-Stokes (RANS-) equation and the Reynolds averaged continuity (RAC-) equation are exact, but unclosed, equations-of-change for the mean velocity field and the mean pressure field. By definition, the normalized Reynolds (NR-) stress is a symmetric and non-negative (i.e., realizable) operator; therefore, all solutions to an NR-stress closure model must be symmetric and realizable (i.e., eigenvalues must be real and non-negative).

 Although current computer hardware and software technologies have advanced significantly since the 1960s, NR-stress closure models have not changed much. Presently, almost all simulations of turbulent flows in industry (and academia) are based on an eddy viscosity hypothesis introduced in the 1880s by Boussinesq and others. This hypothesis, which assumes that hydrodynamic velocity fluctuations are similar to molecular scale fluctuations, is not consistent with experiments or with classical continuum mechanics.

 As noted above, the NR-stress operator must be symmetric and realizable for all turbulent flows, but it is not an objective operator inasmuch as turbulent fluctuations are directly affected by the symmetric and the antisymmetric components of the mean velocity field. Consequently, eddy viscosity models are unable to predict the low-order statistical properties of any turbulent flow field.  

 Market Need   A market assessment related to the use of computational fluid dynamics (CFD) in the automotive sector clearly identified a need for a next generation RANS/NR-stress model with the following characteristics: the model must be calibrated, realizable, accurate, and converge rapidly. It should be able to simulate flows within different complex spatial domains without changing the calibration. The low-order statistical model should quantitatively predict the following flow properties: components of the mean velocity field; the mean pressure field; the mean temperature field; the turbulent kinetic energy field; the turbulent dissipation field; and, the components of the NR-stress operator within the flow domain.   

Legacy of Innovation   Ongoing research at Michigan State University (MSU) has developed a new class of algebraic mappings of the NR-stress into itself for all turbulent flows (see Koppula et al. 2013; Koppula et al., 2011; Koppula et al., 2009).  The Universal Realizable Anisotropic PreStress (URAPS-) closure for the NR-stress has been pre-validated by using direct numerical simulation results for rotating and for non-rotating fully-developed channel flows. For a pdf copy of an I-Corps presentation on URAPS, send an e-mail to petty@msu.edu.

Go/No Go   The NSF/I-Corps URAPS-team completed a comprehensive entrepreneur training course during the fall of 2016. The team focused on the need to improve CFD-simulations in support of prototype development in the automotive sector. More than 100 professionals were interviewed by members of the URAPS-team. The market survey confirmed that an improvement in current simulations associated with isothermal and non-isothermal turbulent flows would be welcomed, provided specific threshold performance metrics could be demonstrated by the new approach. The URAPS-team concluded that a new start-up company would not be viable at this time. Instead, a proof-of-concept study of the URAPS-closure should be developed and tested before asking CFD-providers and CFD-users to evaluate the new approach. From December (2016) to April (2017), the URAPS-team conducted additional interviews and market assessments beyond the fall 2016 market discovery workshop. An evaluation of a minimum viable prototype based on the URAPS-closure for non-isothermal turbulent flows was initiated.  Airflow Sciences Corporation (AFS) and Michigan State University (MSU) agreed to form a partnership to test the efficacy of the URAPS-closure. AFS and MSU submitted an NSF Phase I STTR proposal to fund a proof-of-concept study of the RANS/URAPS innovation. Although the proposal was not selected for an award, AFS and MSU continue to seek funding for this initiative.   

 Acknowledgement   The URAPS team members are grateful to the NSF managers and the entrepreneur trainers for the opportunity to participate in this market discovery. We also thank the many scientist, engineers, and managers for taking the time to help us understand the impact of CFD-technology on applications in the automotive industry.

Koppula, K. S., A. Bénard, and C. A. Petty, 2011, “Turbulent Energy Redistribution in Spanwise Rotating Channel Flows”, Ind. Eng. Chem. Res., 50 (15), 8905-8916.

Koppula, K. S., A. Bénard, and C. A. Petty, 2009, “Realizable Algebraic Reynolds Stress Closure”, Chem. Eng. Sci., 64, 4611-4624.
